did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The Reconstruction collection contains general military orders #1 and #11 from the Reconstruction period in Texas history.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The United States Army occupied Texas after the American Civil War as part of a larger effort to occupy former Confederate states and enforce United States law. While some Texans cooperated, others sought to return the state to as close to antebellum Texas as possible. The Army was withdrawn in 1870 with the election of Edmund J. Davis as governor and readmission of Texas to the Union, ending military rule in Texas. The army's role of centralized law enforcement was inherited by the state militia and state police, answerable to the governor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Reconstruction collection contains general military orders #1 and #11 from the Reconstruction period. General Order #11, from 1865, requires all people in Texas to turn in any state records that they personally held to the provisional governor of the state. General Order #1, from 1868, provides for the appointment of United States General J.J. Reynolds to command of the Fifth Military District, which included Texas. At the time, the states that had composed the Confederate States of America were divided into military districts, each with a military commander in charge of the military and political affairs of the state.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Reconstruction collection was arranged in one folder with a title. Currently, the Reconstruction collection is arranged in one series: Military Orders.
